spec.description:
**Galera Cluster — Production**

Production MariaDB Galera cluster monitoring. Tracks cluster membership, replication health, query performance, connection saturation, and node resources. Top rows show current cluster state for at-a-glance health checks. Lower rows provide detail for troubleshooting.
Shows inbound and outbound network traffic to and from the cluster.
spec.title: Cluster network traffic

spec.description: Average query execution time per node. Spikes indicate slow queries, lock contention, or resource pressure. Correlate with flow control and replication queue panels to determine if the cause is Galera-related or query-level.
spec.title: ⭐ Average Query Response Time

spec.description: Whether each node is accepting client queries. ON (1) means the node is part of the cluster and serving traffic. OFF (0) means the node has lost cluster membership or is in a non-operational state. Any node showing OFF is a P1 incident — it is dropping all client connections.
spec.title: Ready to Accept Queries

spec.description: Shows the number of nodes in the cluster over time.
spec.title: Galera cluster size

spec.description: Current Galera state of each node. Synced (4) is the only healthy production state. Joined (3) means the node has received the full state but is still catching up on the write queue. Donor/Desynced (2) means the node is providing state transfer to another node and may have degraded performance. Joining (1) means the node is actively receiving a state transfer and cannot serve traffic.
spec.title: Local State

spec.description:
Fraction of time each node was paused due to Galera flow control. A slow node causes the entire cluster to pause writes until it catches up. Sustained values above 0 indicate a performance bottleneck that needs investigation.

A value near 0.0 is healthy; 0.2 or higher indicates issues
spec.title: Flow Control Paused

spec.description:
Average number of writesets waiting to be applied on each node. A healthy node keeps this near 0. Sustained values above 0.5 mean the node can't apply incoming writesets fast enough, which will eventually trigger flow control and stall cluster writes.

If you see flow control paused going up, check this panel — if receive queue is growing on a specific node, that node is the bottleneck. Common causes are slow disks, CPU pressure, or large transactions causing apply lag on that node.
spec.title: Receive Queue Average

spec.description:
Average number of writesets waiting to be sent to other nodes. A healthy node keeps this near 0. Sustained values above 0.5 indicate network congestion or other nodes being too slow to accept writesets.

This is the outbound counterpart to the receive queue. If receive queue grows on one node, you might see send queue grow on the other nodes because the slow node can't accept their writesets. If send queue grows across all nodes, it's more likely a network issue rather than a single slow node.
spec.title: Send Queue Average

spec.description:
Rate of transaction certification failures per node. Certification fails when two nodes attempt conflicting writes to the same row simultaneously. Occasional failures are normal under concurrent write load — the failed transaction gets rolled back and the application should retry. Sustained or spiking failures indicate write contention in your application, often caused by multiple nodes writing to the same rows or hot tables.

If you see spikes, look at what your app is writing, not your server resources. Common fixes are directing writes to a single node or redesigning the schema to reduce row-level contention.
spec.title: Certification Failures

spec.description: Read (SELECT) vs write (INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE) throughput across the cluster. Shows overall workload profile and helps identify traffic pattern changes. Sudden drops indicate application issues or connection problems. Sudden spikes may indicate runaway queries or unexpected load.
spec.title: Queries Per Second by Type

spec.description: Rate of queries exceeding the long_query_time threshold per node. Check your current long_query_time setting — the default of 10 seconds only catches extreme cases. Consider lowering to 1-2 seconds for more useful signal. Spikes here correlate with query response time increases and may indicate missing indexes, lock contention, or schema issues.
spec.title: Slow Queries Rate

spec.description: Percentage of max_connections in use per node. When a node hits 100%, new connections are refused and your application starts failing. Sustained values above 80% warrant increasing max_connections or investigating connection leaks.
spec.title: ⭐ Connection Usage

spec.description: Rate of failed connection attempts per node. Causes include authentication failures, exceeding max_connections, or network issues between application and database. Spikes here often correlate with application deployments, credential changes, or connection pool misconfiguration.
spec.title: Aborted Connections

spec.description:
Number of threads actively executing queries per node, not just connected but idle. This is your real-time load indicator. A healthy node typically has single-digit values. Sustained spikes mean queries are piling up rather than completing, indicating lock contention, slow queries, or resource exhaustion. If threads running approaches threads connected, the node is saturated.

A connection is an established session between your app and MySQL — it exists even when idle, doing nothing. A thread running means that connection is actively executing a query right now.
spec.title: Threads Running

spec.description: CPU utilization per node. Sustained high CPU on a single node can cause replication apply lag and trigger flow control across the cluster.
spec.title: CPU Usage per node

spec.description: Memory utilization per node. MariaDB relies heavily on the InnoDB buffer pool for performance. High memory pressure can cause swapping, which drastically increases query response times and replication lag.
spec.title: RAM Usage per node

spec.description: Disk utilization per node and partition. MySQL data partition filling up is a P1 emergency — the node will crash. OS disk filling up (from logs, binlogs, or GRA files) can also cause failures. Monitor both partitions.
spec.title: ⭐ Disk Usage per Node

spec.description: Average time for writesets to replicate between cluster nodes. Baseline for same-subnet nodes should be under 1ms. Sustained increases indicate network issues, node resource pressure, or large transactions slowing replication.
spec.title: ⭐ Replication Latency (ms)

spec.description: Total queries per second per node. Shows how load is distributed across the cluster. Uneven distribution may indicate load balancer misconfiguration or application routing issues. Sudden drops on a single node suggest connectivity problems.
spec.title: Queries Per Second per Node
Galera Cluster Monitoring Dashboard
